ygData.subject: Re: [cantera] C++ help ( beginner) [and thoughts on Windows vs. Mac]
ygData.msgSnippet: I infer from your statement include c: .. that you are doing this on a PC...  From the form of the error statement, I m guessing you are using Visual C++.

I infer from your statement 'include "c:\.."' that you are doing this 
on a PC...  From the form of the error statement, I'm guessing you are 
using Visual C++.  If so, you need to set some project parameters when 
you create a new project.  The easiest thing to do is add your project 
to the same workspace as the rest of Cantera, and specify that it 
depends on all of the other projects.  Also, you will need to change 
some of the default settings for Fortran and C++ to match the settings 
for the other Cantera projects.

The basic problem here is that I no longer use a Windows PC for Cantera 
development, so the Windows compile/build procedure tends to get out of 
date until someone points out a problem and I fire up the old Windows 
laptop to see what is wrong... This is at best a short-term solution, 
because I don't even have the latest Microsoft compilers (.NET) or 
Intel Fortran, which I understand is the one to use together with 
Visual Studio .NET.  Since I'm not planning to go back to Windows 
(except to build Windows versions of Cantera), some knowledgeable 
Windows/C++ user needs to step up and become the maintainer of 
Windows-specific aspects of Cantera, or else it may become more and 
more difficult to keep the Windows version up to date.

Another alternative for users is to switch to Mac OS X or to linux (or 
some other unix).  I can attest that Mac Powerbooks running OS X are 
really very nice, and run all of the usual unix/gnu tools, including X 
Windows.  Of course, you also get freedom from most viruses, worms, 
etc.  Cantera builds without problem on OS X, just like it does on 
linux.  The only drawback I have found is that the mouse only has one 
button, not two (or three) but you get used to that.  Interoperability 
with Windows is very good - you can share network drives, email Office 
documents to/from PCs, etc. For what it's worth, here's what Bill Joy, 
a founder of Sun Microsystems and the developer of Java, has to say 
about Mac OS X:

http://www.wired.com/wired/archive/11.12/billjoy.html

Just a thought.

Dave

>
